Journal.Title: International journal of environmental research and public health
Journal.ISOAbbreviation: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Article.ArticleTitle: Temporal Cross-Correlations between Ambient Air Pollutants and Seasonality of Tuberculosis: A Time-Series Analysis.

AbstractText: The associations between ambient air pollutants and tuberculosis seasonality are unclear. We assessed the temporal cross-correlations between ambient air pollutants and tuberculosis seasonality. Monthly tuberculosis incidence data and ambient air pollutants (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>)) and air quality index (AQI) from 2013 to 2017 in Shanghai were included. A cross-correlogram and generalized additive model were used. A 4-month delayed effect of PM<sub>2.5</sub> (0.55), PM<sub>10</sub> (0.52), SO<sub>2</sub> (0.47), NO<sub>2</sub> (0.40), CO (0.39), and AQI (0.45), and a 6-month delayed effect of O<sub>3</sub> (-0.38) on the incidence of tuberculosis were found. The number of tuberculosis cases increased by 8%, 4%, 18%, and 14% for a 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> increment in PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, and NO<sub>2</sub>; 4% for a 10 unit increment in AQI; 8% for a 0.1 mg/m<sup>3</sup> increment in CO; and decreased by 4% for a 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> increment in O<sub>3</sub>. PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentrations above 50 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, 70 μg/m<sup>3</sup> for PM<sub>10</sub>, 16 μg/m<sup>3</sup> for SO<sub>2</sub>, 47 μg/m<sup>3</sup> for NO<sub>2</sub>, 0.85 mg/m<sup>3</sup> for CO, and 85 for AQI, and O<sub>3</sub> concentrations lower than 95 μg/m<sup>3</sup> were positively associated with the incidence of tuberculosis. Ambient air pollutants were correlated with tuberculosis seasonality. However, this sort of study cannot prove causality.
